reviewText:
Putt Putt Saves the Zoo is one of the best games in existance, while people might argue that GTA or Elder Scrolls is better, they clearly haven't played Putt Putt.

Pros:
Cheap ($6.99) [2.79 at the time of this review]
Teaches you how to drive
Great dialogue
Intense gameplay featuring the life and death situations of baby animals
A++ voice acting from some of the best in the business
Fun minigames for some side action
Fluid animation
Brilliant storyline
HOT ZIGGITY

Cons:
Bugs (i encountered one animation glitch with the lion cub, which did not affect gameplay)

TL;DR:
A 12/10 game for a cheap price that will make your friends jealous.
voteText: 61 of 65 people (94%) found this review helpful 53 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This is, by far, my favorite Putt-Putt game in the series.

I don't know about anyone else, but when I was younger, I used to wrap myself in a blanket, drinking hot cocoa, immersed in this game. Even though I am nearly an adult, I still enjoy and absolutely adore this game.

Just as the name implies, the zoo is in trouble, and it is up to Putt-Putt, along with his pet dog Pep, to help out. From icy terrain to the heart of the jungle, Putt-Putt must save animals scattered throughout the field.

One of my favorite things to do with each Putt-Putt game is that you can change the color. It's a little feature added to the series, but I always liked how you could paint this little fellow. (I always color him blue).

Despite the dusty years, Putt-Putt Saves the Zoo, and all games for that matter, continues to shine. The memories left behind gives nostalgia a warm welcome.

reviewText: I have had this game since 2000 (Orignally came out 1995). Its nice to see that older games can come to sites like Steam in order to work on newer computers. This game is very low paced, which is great for smaller children. Its your typical 90's point-and-click game. Most objects that you click make funny actions and sounds. Its a unique feature that you dont see in many games now days. It gives you a smile. It really doesnt last that long, probably lasts about 1 hour at most, but its still somewhat fun. If you have the time,  want to get your child into gaming, or just in the mood to play a low paced game, heres a good game to play.

reviewText: During the late 90’s/early 2000’s Humongous Entertainment released an absolutely fantastic stream of “edutainment” point and click adventures for children. These titles focus on a range of light academics including basic geography, basic to upper elementary level mathematics, logical thinking, critical thinking and puzzle solving, topped off with reinforcement of good manners and polite social etiquette. At the lower end of the age spectrum, they may require some adult supervision and supportive guidance, but there is no better series of games for a child’s first venture into PC gaming.\n\nPutt-Putt Saves the Zoo is the pinnacle of the Putt-Putt Franchise. Between that absolutely brilliant opening theme and the best arctic exhibit in all of gaming, Saving the Zoo will forever hold the trophy for best Putt-Putt game of all time in my mind. To this very day I will shamelessly replay this game and enjoy it every bit as much as when I was a child. My children WILL grow up with this game in their lives and your kids should as well.

Once you get to the zoo, you are greeted by another ethnic stereotype as Outback Al" orders you too return the animals he views as his property. reviewText:
When the Humongous games first came to Steam (on my birthday no less!), I was so excited! I looked through all the choices and saw most of my favorite Humongous titles, buying each one. However, much to my sadness, I did not see Putt-Putt Saves the Zoo, which happens to be my all-time favorite. Ever since that day, I periodically checked Steam to see if they'd ever put it up and sure enough, today, I saw it and instantly bought it! I couldn't be happier! The game still stands the test of time and is as great as I remembered it! The style, the voice acting, all the little stuff you can do and listen to... It's perfect. Thank you Humongous for bringing me so much joy as a kid AND an adult. I'm so glad I know the good that you did in the early 90s and I think it helped me and many others become better people.

And thank you Steam for bringing these joyful, colorful games to your roster. Never stop being beautiful.

If you're a parent who's looking for a game that will leave a great impression on your young children or even just a person who wants to play a fun, early point-and-click adventure, this is the game for you!

reviewText:
I is not often I get lost in a game like I did with Putt Putt Saves the Zoo.  Everything about this game screams quality and adventure. A much improved third-person view, amazing music, a living breathing world, a menu-system that's amazing and a game filled with interesting stuff to do. Truly a masterpiece.

The dynamicness and sheer volume of random quests means that the open world aspect is never the same thing twice. And if you forgo the linear main quest and faction quests to craft your own adventure, the games replayability value increases ten fold. However, I would issue a warning to my fellow low graphic computer folk. The fade in and out range of enemy NPC's and whatnot can make this game extra challenging if you prefer the stealthy approach to combat. Nevertheless, it can be compensated for with sufficient wit and guile on your part.

Pros:
-Stunning visuals
-Vast landscapes to explore
-There's just so much to do
-So much detail in the game
-NPC's feel very much like individuals
-Quests have their own interesting storylines
-Great soundtrack. (Always sets the atmosphere perfectly)
-Great voice acting

Cons:
-Bugs (They are pretty rare)
-Fairly repetitive dialogue (Understandable considering the amount of things in this game.)

TLDR: It's the best game I ever played, and I would recommend everyone to buy it. It formed the basis for games like Skyrim, GTA and Final Fantasy.   10/10

reviewText: From this game forward, there is a noticable increase in the quality of games from Humongous Entertainment.  The animation, writing, sound quality, art style, and almost every other element of these games just looks and feels SO much better than even the games that were released 1 or 2 years earlier.\n\nAs a result, this game is actually not too bad.  Yes, it's still a kid's game, so it's not exactly challenging or even super interesting for us adults, but it's still pretty fun if you are playing it for the nostalgia.  If you missed the HE bandwagon as a kid and want to see what the fuss is all about... well, personally I would skip Putt-Putt altogether, because the other series are a lot more fun for anyone over 8 years old.  Regardless, this game is still pretty charming, and I think that most people can enjoy themselves even without nostalgia to provide extra hype.

reviewText: This is the best Putt-Putt game and the one that became the prototype for the rest of the series. Each of the six animals needs an item to rescue and it's not as linear as the other games... even if it's a 45 minute long game for children. This one is a big step up from the first two, which I still do like. It has a pong/hockey minigame that's the first kinda fun minigame in the Putt-Putt series! This was also the first Putt-Putt to make me legitimately laugh at a dumb joke as an adult. If you're reliving some Putt-Putt I'd recommend this one along with Joins the Circus.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Putt-Putt Saves the Zoo is probably my favourite out of all the Putt-Putt games, and was even as a kid.  Of the ones I played back then, this one was also probably the biggest time sink.  I just played it in about an hour, which included playing the story, taking photos, and mucking about with the mini games.

The game is pretty self explanatory, but regardless: Putt-Putt has to save the zoo by helping the animals find their places.  Of course, this might have some adults raising their eye brows, as you likely come ot realize that not only is the actual zoo keeper oddly unorganized, but the zoo seems fairly hazardous to a visitor's health between the swing entrances, accidents, etc.

Between exploring the areas, clicking on everything, playing the games, and more you could spend quite a bit of time with your child on this game.  The main point of the game is teaching about the animals, clearly, along with some problem solving skills (How do you warm something up?  How do you fix something that is broken?).

Also, when it comes to the credits, don't exit immediately.  Just as with the rest of the game, there are things in the credits for a player to click on, to hear noises, watch animations, and even see the people behind the voices of the game.

reviewText:
An Instant Childhood Point-and-Click Classic from the Days of my Childhood, which consist of the old MS-DOS, Windows 3.1, Windows 95, Windows 98 & Windows 98SE PCs. Another Personal Favorite game of mine in which you help Putt-Putt recuse 6 of the missing baby animals: Baby Jambo the Elephant, Masai the Giraffe, Kenya the Lion Cub, Zanzibar the Hippo, Sammy Seal, and Little Skeeter the Snake, so that Outback Al can Open the Cartown Zoo.

Putt-Putt Saves the Zoo has also been to known to win several Children's Game Awards:
Kid's Choice Award, Couldn't Peel Me Away, Children's Multimedia Expo 1995
Best Kids Game of 1995, The Computer Show Online
Winner, 1995 National Parenting Center Seal of Approval
1995 Hot Holiday 100, Family Software #4, Computer Gaming World
Top 10, The Computer Museum Guide to the Best Software for Kids
The Best of 1995, Mac Home Journal
The Best of 1995, Editor's Choice, PC World
1996 Family PC Tested, Recommended
100 Best Discs Ever, CD-ROM Today
1996 Rommie Awards, Best Game for Kids, CD-ROM Today
1996 Parenting Magazine Software Magic Award
Medallion Award, Anders 1997 CD-ROM Guide
Most Popular Character Ever, Home PC Kids' Lab
All Star Software, Children's Software Revue
CNET Top 100 CD-ROMs Award; Buy It! Award
1996 Kids First Award, Coalition for Quality Children's Media

reviewText:
Don't buy this game if you're a real gamer like me.

I bought this while really high after watching Fast and Furious 6, looking for a sick car game to do skids and burnouts.
Thinking you can drive whilst in a zoo like environment sounded like a great time to me. But I was solely disappointed.
Not only can you not drive in this game, but you can not do burnouts OR skids. You are a deranged car with a mouth and eyes with a dog in the back.

You click on areas and your flamboyant car drives to that location in the most UNCOOL way ever. The car spins like its made of jello then flies to the direction with a dumb smile on its face. The voice actor for this car is also extremely annoying, I turned off the sound and tried putting on subtitles but I couldnt find how to do it so I guess these developers hate deaf people and dont want them playing their garbage racing game where you cant even race.

So you might be asking Well it has cars in it
date: what type of racing game is it?"\nI'll tell you: None. It's not a racing game at all! The racing is replaced with click movement
recommended: the power-ups is replaced with an inventory. The inventory
hoursPlayed: you ask? Well it is basically like the trunk of the car
voteText: but since the car doesn't have a driver (which makes no damn sense) he has to have hooks installed so that he grabs stuff. Why not just have a driver? The incompetent writing doesn't stop there though.\n\nNot only is there no action
helpfulPercent: or subtle sexual undertones; but there is also no words to describe how bad this game is.\n\nThe only people that would like this game are fat losers
votesHelpful:
because theyve got fat loser trucks in the game too.
Not one relatable character. I searched high and low for a sick army truck with slicked back hair or even a surfer truck but NOTHING relatable to their core gaming audience was even found.

Final Score: I give this game 3 out of 10 brooms. Broom broom broom! (Revving the engine)

If you want to go REALLY fast try out the new Need for Speed™ game on Origin™

reviewText: Never have I seen a more compelling and heart wrenching tale from any other game. The way the narrative strives to socially commentate on all of the world's worst issues and it's incredibly accurate depiction of war and poverty is only the beginning of why this game deserves Game of the Year Edition 1995. My particularly favourite scene was the delivery of a very powerful line by Putt Putt as he says I'll have some Cheese Squigglies
date: please". You can just tell how much emotion the voice actor put into this role considering Putt Putt has been suffering from PTSD since the aftermath of "Putt Putt Joins the Parade". Simply incredible stuff.\n\nOh and how could I not forget the romance that develops between Zanzibar the Hippopotamus and Sammy Seal. Sensational. 3 thumbs up. 6 stars. WouldPlayAgain/10"

reviewText:
Wonderful trip into nostalgia land!

This was my favorite game as a kid. I was hesistant to pick it again in case it ended up not being as good as I remembered, but in the end I'm glad I did.

Pros:
-The art holds up well for a 20-year-old game
-Lots of fun things to click in the background
-Great music
-Good voice acting
-The hockey mini-game is actually challenging.

Cons:
-Very short; you can play it in one sitting easily. It says I've played for 4+ hours, but that's decieving since I left it up on my computer while I did other things for a while. Expect more like 20-45 minutes depending on how much you explore.
-Not much replay value.

reviewText:
Summary:
Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo is an action packed puzzle adventure game created by Humongous Entertainment[en.wikipedia.org]. Putt-Putt® helps a zoo find and rescue baby animals while overcoming obstacles.

Story/Plot/Setting:
The story follows a purple car named Putt-Putt®, he travels around the world helping strangers with his pal Pep. The gang finds themselves visting Baldini the owner of Baldini's Grocery Store" Baldini asks Putt-Putt if he and Pep could deliver zoo chow to the Cartown Zoo
date: Putt-Putt happily agrees and went off to deliever the zoo chow. Aproaching and entering the Cartown Zoo
recommended: Putt-Putt greets and delivers the zoo chow to Outback Al. Outback Al tells Putt-Putt about how horrible his morning was and how Outback Al needed to repair bridges
voteText: and find missing baby animals. As always Putt-Putt graciously tells the owner of the Outback Zoo he'll find the six young animals
column16:
and Little Skeeter the snake and return them to their loving parents. It's up to Putt-Putt® to save the children and reunite them with their parents.

Gameplay/Content/Controls:
The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from the Putt-Putt® franchise
column17:
simple but hard to master.  Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo is filled with charming sound effects.

Positives
+Big and bold presentation
The Putt-Putt®  production is just as big and bold as it ever was. In fact
column18: it's even more so in this sequel: along with some of the best visuals the PC
column20:
& Linux has ever seen.

+Incredible music
Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo has a variety of music composed by several people. The music in Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo makes you feel many emotions
column24: et cetra. My personal favorites are Penguin Boogie
column26:
and Where's Masai?/Masai's Story.

+Still looks fantastic
Putt-Putt®  Saves The Zoo still looks gorgeous to this day. You can tell the developers put a lot of sweat
column28:
and tears into this game. Many developers still try to make their art style resemble to Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo.

+Long-lasting appeal
Putt-Putt®  Save The Zoo has a lot long-lasting appeal. It has an enormous amount of collectables and replay ability. There are major plot points that can effect your story and your character Putt-Putt®.

+ Avalible on PC
column30:
and Linux
Yes you read that correctly. Putt-Putt®  Saves The Zoo is avalible on any operating system so no one's left out. You can see how much the developers and producers care for the consumers.

Oscar-quality story
Redirect back to Story/Plot/Setting

Negatives
-They only charged $6.99 for this video game.
The developers and publishers were too generous on the price of this game.

In short
column31: Putt-Putt® Saves The Zoo is an excelent action packed puzzle adventure game anyone can play and enjoy. 10/10 Masterpiece"

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Putt-Putt Saves the Zoo, considered one of the most revoluntionary JRPGs of all time, has finally come to Steam. This Bioware game used to be an Xbox 369 exclusive, but now it's on PC (with mod support).

The Story:
After waking up to finding his father murdered, Putt-Putt goes on a daring mission to find out who killed her dad. The story puts Kill la Kill to shame. I highly recommend it for fans of horror and romance.

The Gameplay:
A lot of people compare this game's combat to CS:GO, but this game was actually the first FPS game ever made. You can also 360 MLG Trickshot some scrubs, but that takes serious skill. I constantly practice this game with my friends. I even landed a triple collateral once.

The Verdict:
Buy this game. This game is up there with classics such as Dream Lights 2: Electric Boogaloo, and Carl on Duty: Black Cops.
